DOC.brief_summary: The goal of this prospective randomized study is to compare the effect of operator experience on the ability to use fiberoptic-guided intubation in children less than two years old, with and without the use of an air-Q as a conduit. The question the investigators are trying to answer is: Does the operator experience make a significant difference in the time for successful fiberoptic guided tracheal intubation with and without the use of an air-Q intubating laryngeal airway?
DOC.brief_title: Comparison of Fiberoptic Intubation With Fiberoptic Intubation Through an Air-Q Intubating Laryngeal Airway in Infants and Small Children
DOC.detailed_description: The aim of this study is to compare the effect of operator experience on the ability to use fiberoptic-guided intubation in children less than two years old, with and without the use of an air-Q as a conduit. The ease and time for placement of the air-Q, fiberoptic grade of laryngeal view, time for fiberoptic tracheal intubation, and peri-operative complications will also be assessed.
DOC.criteria: Healthy (ASA I to III) children who will be intubated as part of their general anesthesia plan for their scheduled surgeries Age 1 month 2 years Weight 120 Kg Children with active respiratory infection Known history of difficult mask ventilation Diagnosis of a congenital syndrome associated with difficult airway management Airway abnormalities (e.g., laryngomalacia, subglottic stenosis).
